rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I adore Altha. I had her for both GEOG 89 and GEOG/WMST 225. Class is very disorganized but still an easy A. Readings are fascinating. Good discussion. She's very passionate & fun to talk to outside of class. Organization is an issue but I would still recommend. She is the reason I'm a geography major.

She is honestly one of the most enjoyable professors to be around that I have come across at UNC! She is very involved in activism and her community and this translates into her material in a way that is very eye opening and helpful! I have loved her class and would take again! Great professor and person!

I love her! She is one of the best professors I have met in college. I enjoy chatting with her after class and she always gives you the feeling that she is very willing to help! Thank you UNC for hiring such an awesome professor!

She especially did a good job of fairly covering controversial issues. It wasn't hard to figure out what her opinions were, but she stopped well short of any classroom actions I would have found inappropriate. Given that many of her students tend to share her positions, albeit without her tact or professionalism, this stood out to me.
As long as you participate, she will give you a good grade. She lets the class decide what to talk about at length and she is SO friendly and helpful and generally an interesting person.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Great class, although it is required for all environmental science and geography majors. I really enjoyed the modeling environmental systems computer lab work

He's a really nice guy who will try to help you out. He puts a lot on his website, but to do well in the class, you really have to go unless you enjoy the material. Very nice professor who is a good teacher and wants all his students to succeed.
Really nice dude, but hard to understand. Also, he's a bit on the boring side. Nevertheless, you tell he cares a lot about the class.

Great guy, one of the nicest professors around; truly cares about teaching. He can be extremely helpful if you approach him. He has a slight accent, which makes him hard to understand, but other than that, he's awesome.

May be the smartest person you will have the pleasure of listening to. Is an incredibly capable quantitative scientist. If you are interested in remote sensing and ecosystem modeling you will learn TONS from this class. Highly Recommended!
aweful
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: He never answered emails, didn't really stick with the syllabus. He wasn't very helpful even when contacted multiple times.
He was the most disorganized and least helpful professor I have had at UNC so far.

I recommend this class to everyone as it's relevant to everyone. It was a fairly depressing class--global warming and all--but I learned a lot. It was definitely not easy. I busted by tail for a B+, but I enjoyed it. He's laid back w/ a California accent, sitting cross-legged on the desk, cracking jokes. And he's really interested in the material.
Dr. Moody is interesting, funny, and knows what he's talking about. If you're interested in environmental science, definately take this course.
Dr. Moody is really engaging - his classes are a hoot! He may not always be organized but he always interesting material to present. Plus, he is a total hottie!!!

This class was a total waste of time.  no organization in his teaching.  no use of books assigned, thus lecture is always mandatory, yet you never know what will be included on the tests.  he goes off on tangents and tests you on them.  Do Not Take One Of His Classes!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Not a terrible class, nor a fun one.  His tests questions are very obscure and have ambiguous wording.   if you are good with conceptualization, take this class but don't expect  to get above an 85% (even after understanding everything on his power points).

Konrad is a great guy, but his tests are tough, even if you pay attention in every lecture and take notes. If you haven't had any environmental science or weather classes in the past, I wouldn't recommend starting out with this class.

Geography 111: Weather and Climate... sounds easy right? It's actually much harder than you think. Konrad does a good job of explaining the information in his lectures (make sure to attend lectures because entire tests are based of lectures). He's very helpful in his offers hours and encourages question. Tests are difficult but study and it'll be k

Kondrad is a really nice guy and really does want to help you if you're willing to put in the effort. He knows his stuff and is very passionate. Do be careful though his test are tricky and questions can be ambiguous. I wouldn't just take this class for funzies but if you need it for a major it's an okay one to take.

Not exactly an easy A, or even an easy B. His test and quiz questions seem random and kind of ambiguous. Class attendance is definitely mandatory. A lot of effort has to be put in to get a good grade. Nice guy though, pretty funny.

If you are the least bit interested in weather and need an easy class, TAKE THIS! Konrad is the best...attendance is definitely necessary but you will rarely dread going to class. He really knows and is excited about weather so class is always entertaining. He curves like crazy so it is really hard to not get an A in the class.

Konrad is an awesome professor who loves weather. I had him during hurricane season so it was great to discuss the current weather events. Grades consist of weekly quizzes and 3 multiple choice tests. You have to attend class to do well as all the material is drawn from lecture not from the book. I'd recommend it

The lecture are taught in a very straight forward manner, however the tests are a more applied learning format. Because of this discrepancy it is very hard to study. He does adjust the scale of the test though.
SO BORING!  Don't take this unless you have to... lectures are off the wall and hard to follow.  He does assign a project that REALLY helps your grade! Study A LOT and you might make an A

Dr. Konrad is a really great guy & teacher. He's nice and really passionate about his work. He's really understanding and explains things very clearly.  TA's are really nice. Exams are easy and come almost entirely from the notes.

The price of the text book went up our semester, so he canceled it! He's a little eccentric, but he LOVES weather. Weather and Climate itself was occasionally dull even though I love the subject, but the discussions of current weather events were amazing. I enjoyed analyzing the drought in 2007 every Monday with him.
easy if you come to class

BeSt ClAsS EvEr!! All of the notes are online, so study and get participation points and its an easy A- I didnt use the textbook once, so that saved 70 dollars right there. Plus he will scale tests at end of semester! Konrad is passionate about the material he teaches, and always takes class time to discuss current events on the weather channel!

Kind of a boring class, but the material is fascinating once you get past the astronomy stuff. The info is useful all over. Once you get into the severe stuff, it gets really interesting. However, you must pay attention in class and study the powerpoint presentations in conjunction with the book to do well. Otherwise, it's not a difficult class.

Seriously, how can you not love Weather and Climate taught by Chip Konrad! That man is ultra-qualified to teach this course just by his NAME. but seriously, it was WAY easy if you paid attention at all. He's a really great guy too, and LOVES HIS WEATHER! Take him durring Hurricane season!
No Comments
interesting class...sometimes the test questions seemed random and confusing, but overall, not too bad if you went to lecture and did problems from the CD-ROM
kinda boring but not too incredibly difficult

Konrad knows his weather. He'll show satellite images of current weather and try to forecast storms like hurricanes. 1/2 of test questions comes from cd in textbook, other 1/2 is from lecture material, which can be confusing. Weather forecast game counts as extra credit.
I thought he was great. Weather rules!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Martin's class was fairly easy. We had about 4 small assignments (requiring about 2-3 pages of written work), a brief 2-5 minute presentation, a an occasional group assignment, a multiple choice midterm, and a final. Attendance is required and taken note of via sign-in sheet. She is a easy-going and her lectures are interesting.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: LOVED Florin! He's the man. I would take him again, but he's semi-retired. He enjoys the material and you can tell. Sometimes says things that are semi-questionable, but ABSOLUTELY loved him! Would recommend again. Studied for tests reading the textbook only the night before, but I still showed up to class everyday though. Would take again 100%

This is my easiest class of my first semester it saved me.  All the info you need for the tests are straight from his lectures and with a little studying its easy to get an A.  He loves his job and likes to make jokes during class.

VERY easy class. Everything on the tests is in his lectures, so just take notes and pay attention, maybe skim the textbook for extra studying before the test. Much of what he talks about comes from basic history and current events of each region or physical geography (like mountains and rainfall). Papers are also easy to write and graded generously

Definitely go to class.  His tests are almost completely things he's talked about solely in class lectures.  The book is helpful for more information, but not really information on the tests.  Off-topic sometimes and a definite rambler. Must like the class!
He makes you think the test wont be hard, but definitely write down everything he says and make sure you at least skim read before the test. Relatively easy though.

The attendence is not mandatory but I felt that if i did not go then i would miss a whole lot of information that would definitely be on the test. He loved when people asked questions and i didn't think i would be that interested in geography but i loved the class. basically u just have to take good notes and study them.

ok so i thought this class was going to be alot easier than it was. Florin is very boring and most of the time it does not seem that he is on topic. You have to like geog. to understand his class. Test aren't hard but you have to rem. alot.
This is a class everyone must take.  It is very informative and interesting, plus Florin is a great professor.  He sucks with technology, all the ladies think its "cute."

Florin was my favorite teacher of the semester.  His class was very interesting and made me want to take more geography classes.  He was very helpful outside of class too.  I would recomend his class to anyone!

Florin is a great guy, but I found his lectures to be terribly boring.  Perhaps if the subject matter had been more interesting, I would have been more engaged.  He is a little out of touch with modern technology, and a bit scatterbrained.  If you have the patience to put up with a few weaknesses, his class might be ok.  Not one of my favorites.
DO NOT SKIP HIS CLASSES!  That was my only problem with this class.  Florin is a great prof and knows the material well.
Great teacher.
best class i've taken
Best professor I had out of the semester.  He's entertaining and funny in a grandfatherly way, and I always found him engaging even during his tangents.  I would unconditionally recommend Florin.

I agree with the reviewer above.  This guy is almost impossible to follow in class.  Good thing he doesn't give hard tests or everyone would fail.  He also never responded to my emails so he wasn't personally helpful to me when I needed it.
No Comments

He's the weirdest professor I've had. He spends half of the class talking about irrelevant topics--while the rest of the class is devoted to 30 minutes of talking about "x," digressing into tangents probably every 2 minutes. Really easy--really
Very sweet guy, interesting class, not very hard
Really cares about students.
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Interesting to listen to in class,very helpful. Classwork not hard but tests harder than you would expect. Draw a lot from the textbook.

The first half of the class was great. She took a trip to Ecuador for research in the middle of the semester and seemed to check out on us from that point forward. Still, she's an eloquent lecturer and never forces her opinions on the class. Always encourages class discussions. She touts her exams as super-hard, but they're not if you attend class.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Smith is very passionate about geography and knows a lot. She is nice and easy to talk to. We had a unit on the Black Lives Matter movement and it was included on a test we had on class material- which I thought was rather subjective. She is v opinionated on things and sometimes it is overbearing. Should keep political opinions off of class tests

Sara is an amazing teacher and person, I absolutely loved going the her class. Though the class is quite bias towards liberal ideas the class discusses both sides of the issue. The papers were very interesting and not difficult at all. I HIGHLY recommend first years to take this course.
Great professor. Workload is manageable and exams are pretty easy. Very approachable and is always willing to help if you need it. Recommended!

Her lectures were not very clear and generally you're just fine if you view her ppts (which are online) and read the text book. I've already taken the class and I'm still not too sure what the class is even about. She's passionate, but not a great instructor. Pretty easy class. I failed one of the exams (due  to laziness) & still ended up w/ a B

Sara was a great professor. The lectures covered a lot of material, but you could tell that she was passionate about geography. Tests are hard, but projects help bring your grade up. To do well, you have to go to class and keep up with the reading!

Sara is the best. She's very passionate and helpful, and dedicated to explaining geographic concepts to those of us who aren't majors. Class was pretty straightforward, wasn't too hard, and the material was interesting. I would take another class with her!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Great professor. He's very lively & kept me awake despite my tendency to fall asleep in just about all of my classes multiple times a week. Weekly quizzes are harder than they need to be, wish he would've allowed us to get one of the 5 questions wrong without hurting our grade. Lots of reading, but skimming works fine. Tests/papers are easy enough.
Professor Gray is a pretty good teacher.  He certainly knows his lectures well and has a real passion for geography.   If you put in the effort this class is a highly enjoyable one to take.

Lectures were absolutely unendurable. I resorted to playing games on my computer and taking vague notes about the powerpoints he gave (although that's not even necessary, since he posts all the lectures). He is mildly amusing if you get his nonsensical remarks. Reading from the textbook is the best way to get an A, though each chapter is very long.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Painfully wordy.  Yes, painfully.

She is very passionate about inequality, development etc., but i found her lectures incredibly boring. She definitely knows her stuff, but i struggled to pay attention. She posts all her ppts. online, so Id say attendance isn't mandatory. I did about half the reading and did well in the class. The essays aren't too bad, and use her study guides

Havice has a passion for this subject of inequality. She anticipates everyone coming to class, ready to learn from what students have read the night before. The papers aren't too difficult, but it requires to read the readings. Definitely not an easy A, but if you work for it, the A is definitely there. Just go to class and listen, I hardly did...

Unless you are a Geography major and have a dedicated interest do NOT take this course. She usually teaches upper level Geography, and expects each student to have prior knowledge. There's no textbook and she assigns boring, long readings. Only two tests, both are short answer tests and TA's grade papers. Her teaching is very confusing.

I really enjoyed this class. It's not exactly an interesting one to sit through- there were definitely times when it seemed to drag on- but she was very passionate about the content. It made me highly consider Geography as a major. It's not too hard to do well in here if you pay attention in lecture and start the papers early (as I did not lol).
Spare yourself from this class if you can! She doesn't curve at all and the class gets so detailed and boring.

She seems to forget this is an intro course, and that students aren't required to have prior knowledge of many of the topics she goes over and as a result won't go in depth with certain ideas. She is not a very entertaining lecturer and teaches directly off the powerpoint, and the midterm comes directly from the final.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: This prof says it how it is and why it is, so if you're not ready to really delve into a deeper analysis of large, overarching concepts, this class is not for you.  Overall, the class material is super interesting and the prof does a great job of conveying info with urgency, intrigue, and real-ness.

Easily one of my favorite professors at UNC. Dunno why he got bad ratings. He's one of the smartest people I've ever met in the social/cultural geography field. His higher level classes are totally discussion based, which makes immersion into the topics a lot easier. It's hard to drift off and lose interest despite his slightly monotone voice.
The class is not hard, but it is extremely boring. I stopped going to class and only did a couple of the readings for the essay(which was graded easily) and still managed to pull a B in the class.
I don't think he has any idea what he's talking about. He reads straight from the slides almost verbatim. Also, he has misspelled words on his PowerPoints (even though they invented spell check).

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I am obsessed with him & will take more classes with him. He is brilliant & his lectures will often make you think about things in a way you never have before. He is very helpful & truly cares about his students. He has made geography so interesting to me that I'm considering minoring, and I never would've thought I would ever say that. He rocks.

Professor Lentz is very knowledgeable and very helpful. He will answer any questions that you have. There are no tests, a few quizzes, and a few papers. He is pretty strict when grading the paper. He assigned short readings before each class and participation is required. Overall it was a great class and I would take it again.

Professor Lentz makes class enjoyable and really encourages class participation. There are no tests, and very few quizzes, so the majority of your grade comes from papers. If you are a superb writer, then you will be fine, but otherwise, he is a very strict grader and isn't all too  clear on what exactly makes a paper a great paper in his eyes.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Olson is one of the most helpful, genuinely wonderful professors I've ever had. I signed up for her class as an afterthought and became a Geography minor after one semester with her. I took another of her classes the next year because she was so great and I've never met a professor who cares more about what she does and about her students.

This class and Professor Olson are the reasons I decided to become a geography major. She is an excellent and thought-provoking lecturer. For a 100 level class this was more challenging than might be expected, but it was very worth it and the take away is incredible.

Professor Olson is one of the nicest, best, and most enthusiastic professors you will ever find. If you take an intro-level class with her (I had 125), be aware that it's just as difficult (if not more so) as her upper-level class. That being said I still did well in both classes, learned a TON, and absolutely loved every minute of class with her.

I was so excited to take this class, but Prof. Olson made the subject so much harder than what it could have been. Her tests were very hard and I never knew what exactly she was looking for. (Everything is written)

Way too difficult for an intro level class. I was a third year geography major when I took this class and I was well versed in the subject, but the tests even went over my head a couple times. Not an easy grader, slightly condescending, but you will likely learn a decent amount in this class if you really invest in it.
